course.subject: LIFS
course.name: Animal Physiology
course.description: Structure and life processes in animals; neurophysiology; circulation; respiration; digestion and absorption; metabolism and energy regulation; muscle and movement; endocrinology.

reviews.author: ym7135
reviews.title: Overall quite interesting, would definitely recommend as an elective...
reviews.comment_content:
Although it is named Animal Physiology, where you would expect memorising a huge list of muscles, bones and organs, this course actually focuses A LOT of molecular mechanisms and regulatory pathways, so be prepared! Also, be prepared to remember very specific details (e.g. terms, numbers, organs). Overall the content is super heavy and require large amounts of revision and memorization of the lecture powerpoints and lecture videos (don't use any textbook they waste your time)

The course is split into two halves (it actually feels like two very different courses) based on the professor teaching:

Miller (focus on muscles and movement):
1. Muscle  (5 ppts)
2. The Heart and circulatory system (3 ppts)
[Mid term exams]

Pingbo (focus on body communication and regulation):
3. Endocrine System (4 ppts)
4. Digestive System (3 ppts)
5. Nervous System (2 ppts)

My personal difficulty rating of each topic (1 being easy, 10 being hardest):
1. Muscles - 7.5/10, content was very new, mechanism was quite straightforward, a lot of diagrams and numbers to remember specifically.
2. Heart - 2/10, content was almost fully covered from highschool (e.g. IB) and 1902, some parts from muscles will be repeated here again.
3. Endocrine system - 9/10, like the regulation pathways were insane, and you need to know at least 20 hormones, and their negative feedback loop control and all.
4. Digestive system - 7/10, a lot of the content came from 1902, but there are extra parts like in-depth study of parietal cells and pancreatic cells which are extremely complex.
5. Nervous System - 4/10, he sorta rushed through it; he said he would remove parts about the auditory system from exams but it ended up being in the exam. The exam questions for this topic was very mathematical, focus a lot of the equations for this topic.

Exams:
Miller's exam was very straightforward - 20 MCQs (20 points), and 135 points from fill in the blanks. The fill in the blanks is quite creative, sometimes it is labelling a diagram, sometimes you put in a number, or sentence (worth 2-3 points) or it can be in list form. All is direct recall from his ppt - so study that in detail!

Pingbo's exam was slightly more difficult - 40 MCQs, not more than 15 fill in the blanks and some complex math questions on the nervous system (Nernest Equation, they were worth a lot of marks) - I personally found the math questions easy but most of the class skipped them. Issue with his exam was that his MCQ was confusing, like even though I know the content, there are always 2 choices which can be technically correct (a lot of questions and answers were super vague).
reviews.comment_teaching:
Miller (A+ teaching):
- Everyone loves Miller! he gives off this cute grandpa aura and makes all these jokes that make everyone go awwww...   
- He repeats the important points MANY times, so you know what is important; he technically answers all the exam questions indirectly.
- He explains his part very clearly, it all makes sense!
- After finishing one topic (e.g. muscle), he will give a non-graded class quiz of fill in the blanks; which is very close to the exam style.
- He discusses some of his tricky exam questions in class already.
- All his ppts are like 120-150 slides long, don't panic! - a lot of it are fun cartoons or fun stuff, a lot are repeated slides for the sake of what he is going to say, he likes to convey the same message/diagram as shown from various textbooks, and each slide contains small amounts of condensed important info.
- You would have to study over 1000 slides for the mid-term, but the way he made his slides really made it stick to your mind really well.

Pingbo (A teaching):
- A bit more serious compared to Miller, still easy to follow. He tends to not repeat any content so its hard to tell which parts are important - basically his part goes on like a story plot.
- He has relates a lot of his info to diseases, medication and society, and he also make a lot of connections between different topics and sub-topics.
- He includes A LOT of practice MCQ and study questions within his ppt, he usually does iPRS system in class (non-graded), however those questions are easier than his exam questions.
- He has around 60 slides per ppt, but very detailed.


Overall both professors taught well. Focus only on their ppts, don't use any textbook; this course is lecture recorded, I do recommend watching lecture videos - Miller actually discusses tricky questions in class, while Pingbo drops very subtle hints of certain exam questions that you can only possibly answer by what he said.
reviews.comment_grading:
Very straightforward:
Mid term - 50% (Mean around 75%)
Finals 50%  (Mean is 62.6 / 110)

My scores:
Mid-term - 93.4%
Finals - 92%
Eventually my score was around 92.8% ish, and overall 2nd in the class, got an A+.

Mid term exams was a lot more competitive because the content was easier and clear and the exams were direct recall. The class didn't do too well for the finals, questions were far more tricky.

From friends, I have also found out that an A grade requires around 86% overall, A- is around 80-81%. But may vary on your class performance ...
reviews.comment_workload:
Its only prep for exam, but content was like huge - kinda heavy workload, but still manageable.

What I did personally to get an A+:

Mid term:
I went to all classes, after class I watched lecture videos, a lot of the details already stuck in my mind so exam prep was easy (he teaches very well)

Finals:
I attended none of his classes (was busy with projects, woops), and that lead to a lot of procrastination ... I only started to learn the content a week prior to exams - basically I watched all lec vids and took notes, and 2-3 days fully memorizing the pathways; and it did end up going well.

reviews.author: Katkatkathy
reviews.comment_content: The course is quite funny and useful. More like an indepth version of LIFS 1902. Yet, it omits some of the tedious part e.g. kidney, which is good. Although the official syllabus seems to be really board and cover a lot of topics, as Prof. Miller taught relatively slowly, He can never cover the whole scope so he will just examine the topics covered. Usually, the last one or two topics of his part will not show up in the mid-term exam. (Prof. Miller teaches before mid-term and Pingbo after mid-term) The final exam is not accumulative.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof Miller is a funny guy, so much better than Pingbo who is quite boring. Miller likes to repeats the same concept for several times from various approaches so if you do pay attention to class, you can definitely grasp all the concepts easily. And he is a really nice guy, wiling to take  questions and conduct the lesson in a relaxing and interactive atmosphere. While Huang speaks in a boring tone although the content is alright but he can easily hypnotizes me. He does not simply read through lecture notes which is good but also give extra ideas related. And he made a lot of practice questions which are similar to the exam questions.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is not that good. The A-range is quite narrow in whcih you needs to get ~90% to fit in the A range otherwise you will immediate drop to an B+ or wtever. The exam questions are quite easy, MC and fill-in-the-blanks. Miller's paper are quite straight forward so the competition is keen. A lot of students score above 90%. While Pingbo's part is slightly more complicated that requires a indepth understanding of the course content and a good logical thinking in order to get the answer right.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is quite huge as the syllabus is quite informative and indepth. You'd better revise weekly instead of cram all the materials right before the exam which is not feasible as the lecture notes is really really long.

reviews.author: myosin
reviews.title: EXTREMELY BAD GRADE
reviews.comment_content: Look at ustspace comment and it is the same.
reviews.comment_teaching: They taught well, but there were lots of content that you need to study veryyyyyy hard in order to get high marks in the exam.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm: 78/80 (mean: 67)
Final: 70/80(mean: 63) really no idea what's wrong with final exam even though the questions are just straightforward

Overall: 74/80(92.75%) wtf A-?????????????!!!!!!!
Grade: A-

It is absolutely bad grade for this course.
I highly not recommend people to take it as your electives. You can't even get an A even with 92.75%.
reviews.comment_workload:
This course is absolutely high workload, with extremely large amount of content that you need to memorize, especially for the midterm exam.
The final exam is also extremely tricky. Even though the final exam is open-book, there were lots of traps inside that you would not pay attention to. But actually there were many straightforward questions that I don't think I did wrongly. Therefore, I have no idea why I got so many wrong answers. Sometimes I think Canvas system has problem with generating the scores of quiz.

reviews.author: dkdkdk
reviews.title: A lot of content
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Miller:
Nice, calm, he makes gentle jokes
I still wish he could abbreviate his ppt more, bc there are a lot of words on his ppts.
He emphasizes important concepts, so pay attention.

Professor Huang
Also a nice professor
His part is definitely more challenging, as he includes his own interest (auditory system)
He has ppts with dark blue backgrounds, it may be a little hard for students taking notes on printed slides.

Both professors are nice and are willing to answer your questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
Honestly, I don't think it's good grading.
The niceness of the professors makes it seem ok though

Midterm: 75/80    Mean: 67.15   High: 80
Final:      73/80    Mean: 63.2     High: 78
Final Grade: A-

Above 1~1.5 SD will get you A
Mean will get you C+ or B- probably

Note: The exams are pretty straightforward, so make sure you at least memorize the key concepts.
reviews.comment_workload: If you're like me and like to watch recorded lectures right before exams, better study at least a week ahead. There is a lot of content to memorize.

reviews.author: KennyS
reviews.comment_content: At first, prof. MILLER shown us the syllabus of the course and we "wow"ed because there were over 1k page of PPT. But after studying, most of the pages were repeated and he could only teach half of the syllabus.
reviews.comment_teaching: I give A for prof. MILLER because I really love him. He is a kind and funny man who will input many jokes during lecture. I give C for prof. HUANG  because he is rather boring compared to MILLER and he just read the PPT to us.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is average. I got 1 SD above in mid-term and no idea in final exam. And I got B+.
reviews.comment_workload: There is not much to work on. Just mid-term and final exam. Mid-term will be worked in LT-J and all student sit closely together, I believe it is not hard for you to look at others' paper.

reviews.author: RIbtSU
reviews.title: Quite good as an elective
reviews.comment_content:
Mid term
Module I: Muscle and Movement
Module II: The Heart & Circulation of the Blood
Module III: The Lungs and Exchange of Gases

Final
Module V: The Endocrine System
Module VI: Digestion and Absorption
Module VII: Physiology of the Nervous and Sensory Systems
reviews.comment_teaching:
Miller is good. I am a big fan of him since LIFS1902. Actually, I have already fulfilled elective requirements but I still take this course as extra just because I heard that Miller is going to retire this summer. This means this year is the last year that can enjoy Miller's teaching, very sad  :'(       want to cry. This is definitely a loss to Lifs students.

In this course, Miller continues his topics after what have taught in 1902. It is a detailed version of 1902 you can say. Miller's teaching never disappoints you. And the powerpoints are clean enough that you can easily study though there are many schematics. I didn't skip any lectures from Miller. As I said, I take this course just because of Miller XD.

Pingbo I do have not many comments on him because his tone really makes you feel sleepy in most of the time so I basically skip all of the lectures except the last lecture of him.  If you want to know more about Pingbo's teaching you can refer to other posts.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm: 50%
Final: 50%

Miller's exam is quite challenging because the exam has a lot of fill-in-the-blanks. The blanks are sometimes "too blank" that you have no idea what to fill in: Some blanks are long, expecting filling sentences I think. But they are just "too blank" that I dunno what I should fill in.

Pingbo's final is all MCs with 80 questions. It is just tooooo EASYYYYY that I only spent 15 mins to finish it. The remaining time is to pretend to check my paper until half an hour is gone because the rule of final exam not allowing you to leave in the first half hour. TOO Ôº•Ôº°Ôº≥Ôºπ„ÄÇ„ÄÇ„ÄÇRemember to study the MCs in PIngbo's ppts. Some are the same or similar.

My score:

Midterm: 86.8%  (rank 5th of the class, total 164 students)
Final: unknown
Grade: A+  

Though I got A+, a large proportion can contribute to luck as this course is quite competitive. And I actually didn't have enough time to study final. I start to study for the final exam only the day before the final. I spent about 10 hours cramming up the stuff on Pingbo's part. Luckily the final exam is easy or otherwise, I would suck and fuck up.
reviews.comment_workload: Not much workload if you are good at memorization. The exams are quite straightforward so basically just "recite", "recite" and "recite"......

reviews.author: Frankie:)
reviews.title: In-depth Version of LIFS1902
reviews.comment_content:
Midterm from Professor Miller:
Module I:  üí™Muscle and Movement
Module II: ü´ÄThe Heart & Circulation of the Blood
Module III: ü´ÅThe Lungs and Exchange of Gases

Final from Professor Pingbo:
Module V:  üß†The Endocrine System
Module VI:  üç≠Digestion and Absorption
Module VII: üîÆPhysiology of the Nervous and Sensory Systems
reviews.comment_teaching:
Miller's lectures were quite interactive as he brought something funny to the class (e.g. dumbbell to explain isotonic contraction and a blood pressure measurement machine to demonstrate b.p. actually varies among ages.)

As for Pingbo's lectures, nothing special as he simply went through the lecture slides. He will not provide video recordings of his lectures unlike MIller so you will have to join his lecture in person if you wish to. As for me, I skipped almost half of Pingbo's lecture as his lecture notes with his quiz MCQs are already enough for my revision and preparation for the final exam.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading of this course should be normal,

The midterm exam of this course has been changed to 20MCQs+158 fill-in-the-blanksüëª for Miller's part and the time allowed was 80 mins. As for Pingbo's final, the exam format remains to be 80MCQs in 120 mins.

Statistics and Scores for both exams:

Midterm: 91.57% (18/20+145/158 =163/178) Mean:52.24% SD: 22.57 out of 100
Final: Not disclosed

Letter Grade: A+

I would say Miller's part was more demanding as you have to remember and recite lecture notes thoroughly since his fill-in-the-blank part requires direct recall from his lecture notes. However, as Miller will get retired in June this year, the exam format of midterm for this course may be subject to change in the coming year.

As for Pingbo's part, the same exam format as in the pandemic times, 80 MCQs in total and they were quite straightforward with a handful requiring in-depth thinking.(e.g. High blood triglyceride level or insulin will stimulate secretion of growth hormones? )  Do pay attention to which scientist discovered the proton pump as well as invented in virto fertilization. Also the quiz MCQs in his lecture ppt are very useful too, some of the MCQs in the final exam were of exact wordings with those MCQs that appeared in this lecture ppt.
reviews.comment_workload: Light workload if you are good at memorizing stuff. Due to the change of exam format in Miller's part, the spelling of some muscle terminologies were required and this may explain why the mean for midterm is only around 50%.

reviews.author: prayforus
reviews.comment_content:
Mid term
Module I: Muscle and Movement
Module II: The Heart & Circulation of the Blood
Module III: The Lungs and Exchange of Gases
Module IV: The Kidney: Osmoregulation and Excretion
Final
Module V: The Endocrine System
Module VI: Digestion and Absorption
Module VII: Physiology of the Nervous and Sensory Systems
reviews.comment_teaching:
Mid term modules were taught by Prof. Andrew L. Miller.
I would recommend you to attend his lessons as he explained everything clearly. His ppt consist of a lot of slides BUT important slides are repeated for several times so that we can remember the contents well.
The remaining modules were taught by Prof. Huang Pingbo.
Some of the final exam questions are exactly the same as some of the practice questions in his ppt.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid term:
76/80 mean 67
Final:
71/80 mean 63

I got an A- at last
The questions are quite straight forward. You may take this course if you are good at memorising.
reviews.comment_workload: Only a mid term exam and a final exam and no assignments or readings but there are a lot of contents. You need to memorise almost everything in the ppt but you will know which topics are more important if you attend the lessons.

reviews.author: mandywscheung
reviews.title: Good professors
reviews.comment_content:
Prof Miller's part:
1. Muscle and Movement --> 3 ppt
2. Heart and Circulation of the Blood--> 3 ppt
3. Lungs and the Exchange of Gases
4. Osmoregulation and Excretion

Prof Huang's part:
1. Endocrine System --> 5 ppt
2. Digestive System --> 3 ppt
3. Nervous System --> 2 ppt
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Miller was responsible for the first half part, Prof Huang taught the second half.

Prof Miller taught the concepts and knowledge quite clear and detailed, thus slow pace. In my case, he would only examine what he taught, so the midterm scope was less than the planned curriculum.

Prof Huang was also a good professor as he would have some short quizzes and notes for you to practice.
reviews.comment_grading:
Both midterm and final exam weight 50%:

Mid-term: 72/80 (mean: 64)  
Final exam: 60/80 (mean: 58.7)

I got a B

reviews.author: Hate1012
reviews.title: Great course
reviews.comment_content:
Miller (For midterm):
1. Muscles (3 chapters)
2. Heart (3 chapters)
3. Gas exchange (1 chapter due to time constrain)

Pingbo (For final):
1. Endocrine system (5 chapters)
2. Digestive system (3 chapters)
3. Neural system (2 chapters)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Miller:
A very kind, passionate and "christmasy" gentleman with his beard on his face. His PowerPoint is super clear, explicit and on the spot that you can understand the content immediately, lots of illustrations and animation are contained in his notes and he'd remind you several time during the course of why we must remember (kinda big hint for the examination)!!! He's become one my favorite professors at UST!!!!

Prof. Pingbo:
Although he's from China, his accent is a 70% of American and 30% of Chinese, so don't need to worry about that:) His teaching is also good and detail, I seldom see a mainland Prof can organize such clear PowerPoints (Except Robert Qi, he's the best). He's also patient and willing to answer students' question.

Both professors are great at teaching, their PowerPoints are easy to follow.
reviews.comment_grading:
I wouldn't say it is a super good grade course since my friends were above mean in both exams but still didn't get an B or B+.

My results:
Midterm: 75/80 (High 79; Mean 64; Low 35)
Final: 68/80 (High 78; Mean 58.7; Low 33)
Overall: 89.38%
Grade: A-
reviews.comment_workload:
As long as you go through all the lecture notes and pay effort to re-organize them in your own way (especially the those hormones in endocrine system!!!!), I'm sure you are good to go!

Don't be afraid to ask questions via email/ face-to-face, both professors are nice.

reviews.author: Bio Fighter
reviews.comment_content:
Miller's part
I: Muscle and Movement
II: The Heart & Circulation of the Blood
III: The Lungs and Exchange of Gases

Pingbo's part
V: The Endocrine System
VI: Digestion and Absorption
VII: Physiology of the Nervous and Sensory Systems
reviews.comment_teaching:
Miller is a good professor. It is quite interesting to have his lesson. However, in my opinion, his powerpoint is way too messy. Each module is having 3 ppts and each ppt contain ~100 slides.

Pingbo's ppt is much better than Miller. However, his lesson is quite sleepy.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid term: (50%)
MCQs and fill in the blanks

Finals: (50%)
MCQs only
reviews.comment_workload: There is only mid terms and exams .So i think if you manage your time well, the workload should be acceptable.

reviews.author: DemonicMocha
reviews.comment_content:
Curriculum include muscle, nervous system, cardiac, endocrine, digestive system, etc.
There are a lot of modules in the course, but it's unlikely they will finish all the modules in time. So they just test you on whatever they taught. But most topics are fundamental knowledge that are very useful for further study in life science.
Structure of the course is simple, just mid and final exams, suitable for those who dislike taking attendance or doing homework.
reviews.comment_teaching: The first half of the course is taught by an Australian professor Andrew Miller. He is very friendly and has a fun teaching style. Second half is taught by Pingbo, a Chinese professor, which has a more technical teaching style
reviews.comment_grading:
Slightly above mean for both mid and final exams
My grade: B
reviews.comment_workload:
Format of exam varies. It can be fill in the blanks, MC or short question. Fill in the blanks is especially hard because you have to remember all the spelling+ concepts and it normally contribute to a high percentage of the whole exam.

Content of the course is heavy, lots of concepts and technical terms.

reviews.author: chrischrisyiu
reviews.comment_content:
Mid term:
Introduction
Muscle ppt1
Muscle ppt2
Muscle ppt3
Heart ppt1
Heart ppt2
Heart ppt2-1
Heart ppt3

Final:
Endocrine System ppt1
Endocrine System ppt2
Endocrine System ppt3
Endocrine System ppt4
GI system ppt1
GI system ppt2
GI system ppt3
Nervous system ppt1
Nervous system ppt2
reviews.comment_teaching: Just pre read the material and follow Miller's teaching in class, If you understand the content, you can easily memorize the materials. He would emphasize the important parts which will be tested in the mid term exam during the lecture, so you better attend the lecture.
